results.title: The Genie from down under: larceny
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Brendan Maher
results.brief_description: Bruce helps Otto and Conrad get the opal because he thinks they will help him return to Australia. Instead, the von Meisters sell it for 25,000 pounds. It’s now up to the genies to sort the mess out.

results.title: The Genie from down under: wishing and hoping
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: When upper class English girl Penelope Townes finds a magic opal which contains two Australian genies, Bruce and his son Baz, she thinks all her problems are over, and that she can have anything she wants. Bruce, however, has other ideas.

results.title: The Genie from down under: it's my opal and I'll cry if I want to
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Jeremy Swan
results.brief_description: Tour operator, Otto von Meister, and his nephew, Conrad, arrive at Townes Downs with a load of tourists. When he learns about the opal Otto recalls that it belonged to their family years before and he and Conrad are desperate to get it back.

results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, ABC-TV (Australia), British Broadcasting Corporation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones and Esben Storm

results.title: Kiewa catchment farm tree group: a community in action
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. North Central Media Unit, John Atkins and Ian Blythman
results.brief_description: The Kiewa community formed a tree planting group to combat the problems of land degradation due to the impact of agricultural practices, the effect of tourisism in the area and erosion. This video shows how a small community in the alpine area of north-east Victoria, worked together to deal with an environmental problem.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. North Central Media Unit, John Atkins and Ian Blythman

results.title: Horse breaking
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Agrifilm
results.brief_description: Depicts 72 year-old Kel Jeffrey applying his unique and humane method of gaining a horse’s confidence to the point where it will allow a saddle to be placed on its back and a person to ride it.

results.title: The Hearing Process
results.creator_credit: Public Service Board of Victoria and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs
results.brief_description: The Hearing Process is a function of the Victorian Public Service Board. It is freely available to all present and former officers and employees of the Public Service. This process is designed to protect the rights of all Public Service Officers and employees, and to enable staff to seek review of decisions which adversely affect them, other than decisions where another review or appeal body exists. The Victorian Public Service employes approximately 40,000 full and part time people. This video outlines the processes involved in presenting a case against unfair or inequitable treatment in the workplace.

results.title: Organics: food for thought
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mike Laker and Jim Testa
results.brief_description: Organic farmers work with nature rather than against it, a process of positive cooperation with the soil, without the intervention of chemicals, in order to produce a quality product. Filmed on location in Victoria, this video covers the production, marketing, export potential and labelling of organic produce in Australia. It features citrus grower, Robert Ridgewell; bio-dynamic wheat/sheep farmer, John Greenwood; vegetable grower, Neville Cann and Ian Diamond, organic wholesaler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mike Laker and Jim Testa
